item.title: Links
item.description:
• Ens≈ç ‚Äî a writing tool that helps you enter a state of flow.
  • mess with dns ‚Äî perform DNS experiments without consequences.
  • HackerNews blogs newsletter ‚Äî a substack blog aggregating on a daily basis blog entries submitted toHackerNews.
  • DevDocs ‚Äî combines multiple API documentations in a fast, organized, and searchable interface.
  • The Punctuation Guide ‚Äî The web‚Äôs most comprehensive guide to American punctuation.
  • Goodreads HTML formatting ‚Äî Goodreads supports a set list of html tags that you can use to format your comments, reviews, and stories & writing.
  • A List of Hacker News‚Äôs Undocumented Features and Behaviors
  • Excalidraw ‚Äî a virtual collaborative whiteboard tool that lets you easily sketch diagrams that have a hand-drawn feel to them.
  • LessWrong ‚Äî an online forum and community dedicated to improving human reasoning and decision-making. We seek to hold true beliefs and to be effective at accomplishing our goals. Each day, we aim to be less wrong about the world than the day before.
  • Obsidian Roadmap ‚Äî list of futureObsidian features.

item.title: üå¥ Jungle
item.description:
Welcome to the üå¥ Jungle!

What is this?

I‚Äôve been using Obsidian for some time already and I found it to be a great place for storing information in a loosely-manner, so it can be retrieved at a later time. I was thinking about publishing my notes for some time, but I wanted to do so in a more controlled way.

Also, I‚Äôve been toying with an idea to add recipes and short notes sections to my website. Frankly, I lacked the motivation to create new subpage templates with the necessary functionality.

Meet üå¥ Jungle!

üå¥ Jungle is mostly an experiment; it‚Äôs a digital garden of sorts. I‚Äôm planning to publish some of my Obsidian notes here, so that they can be easily accessed by me and my friends, on any device.

Why not publish on madebyme.today?

I‚Äôve established an unwritten contact between me and my readers ‚Äî madebyme.today is for tech-related articles. I feel like if I‚Äôd publish a TTRPG session log or a cinnamon roll recipe on my website, I‚Äôd break that contract.

Think of it like this:

  • madebyme.today is only for tech,
  • üå¥ Jungle is not only for tech ‚Äî it is more Kamil.

What can I find here?

Who knows? ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

The notes are kind of unstructured ‚Äî I‚Äôll put here anything I‚Äôm willing to share with the internet ‚Äî and only marginally reviewed before publishing, so you can expect typos and 404s.

Is it published with Obsidian Publish?

No.

Obsidian Publish is a great tool, but it does not allow you to fully customise the static website it produces. For this project I‚Äôve decided to go with Quartz by Jacky. Quartz is a static-site generator ‚Äî like Hugo ‚Äî but it was built with Obsidian in mind; it handles Wikilinks, Callouts, and many other Obsidian features out-of-the-box.

item.title: 001 - Yellow pea soup
item.description:
Ingredients

  • 1 small onion
  • 1 small carrot
  • 1 clove of garlic
  • 2 pcs of celery
  • 4 cups vegetable broth
  • 1 ¬º cup yellow peas
  • 1 tsp dried oregano
  • ¬Ω tsp dried thyme
  • Salt and pepper

Preparation

  1. Finely chop the onion and celery, slice the garlic, and dice the carrots.
  2. Put all ingredients into the rice cooker pot and mix thoroughly.
  3. Close the lid, select the SOUP program and cook for 2 hours.

TIP: Add a tablespoon of cream to the soup and blend with a stick blender.

item.title: 002 - Vegetable Thai curry
item.description:
Ingredients

  • 1 small onion
  • 1 medium carrot
  • 1 red pepper
  • 230 g broccoli
  • 130 g peas
  • 3 tbsp Thai red or yellow curry paste
  • 200 ml coconut milk
  • 100 ml water
  • 1 tbsp brown sugar
  • 1 tbsp fish sauce

Preparation

  1. Finely chop the onion, peel and dice the carrots, cut the pepper into strips and place in the rice cooker pot along with the peas, curry paste, water and sugar.
  2. Close the lid, select the SLOW COOK program and cook for 45 minutes.
  3. 10 minutes before the end of the cooking time, add the broccoli florets, coconut milk, and fish sauce to the pot. Close the lid again and let the program finish.
  4. Stir thoroughly before serving.

TIP: As a side, serve with sticky rice or white bread.

item.title: 003 - Spanish chicken with rice
item.description:
Ingredients

  • 500 g chicken cutlets
  • 1 onion
  • 3 garlic clovers
  • 1 ¬Ω cups rice
  • 2 cups chicken broth
  • 400g chopped tomatoes (sterilised)
  • 1 tbsp butter
  • 1 tsp ground cumin
  • 2 tbsp chopped parsley
  • Salt and pepper

Preparation

  1. Finely chop the onion, chop the garlic and put them in the rice cooker pot. Add the rinsed rice, broth, butter, cumin, salt and pepper, and stir thoroughly.
  2. Pour in the tomatoes and add the chicken (cut into large strips) on top. Do not stir.
  3. Close the lid, select the QUICK COOK program and cook for 35 minutes.
  4. Stir again before serving.

TIP: Serve sprinkled with freshly chopped parsley.

item.title: 004 - Hong Kong clay pot rice
item.description:
Ingredients

  • 1 ¬Ω cups jasmine or basmati rice
  • Smoked pork belly (approx. 3 cm wide)
  • 1-2 sausages (to taste)
  • 2 ¬Ω cups water
  • 2 tbsp soy sauce
  • 1 tbsp fish sauce
  • ¬Ω tsp sugar
  • ¬Ω tsp white pepper
  • 5 sage leaves

Preparation

  1. Put the rinsed rice, the whole piece of pork belly, sausages, sage, and water in the rice cooker pot.
  2. Close the lid, select the CLAYPOT RICE program and start it.
  3. When the rice is ready, (in about 30 minutes) take out the pork and sausages, and cut them into slices.
  4. Mix the soy sauce, fish sauce, and all other spices together. Add this to the pot along with the meat.
  5. Close the lid and let the program finish.

TIP: Serve in bowls drizzled with soy sauce and add freshly chopped corriander.

item.title: 005 - Oatmeal porridge with apples and cinnamon
item.description:
Ingredients

  • 1 apple
  • 1 cup oatmeal
  • ¬Ω inch cinnamon
  • 1 tbsp brown sugar or honey
  • 1 ¬æ cups water
  • a pinch of salt

Preparation

  1. Place the diced apple, oats, super, cinnamon, ad pinch of salt, and water in the rice cooker pot.
  2. Close the lid, select the PORRIDGE program and cook until the desired consistency has been reached (approx. 10-15 minutes).
  3. This program can also be stopped manually. It is not necessary to wait till the end of the set time.

TIP: Serve with fresh raspberries or other delicious fruits.

item.title: 001 - Callouts
item.description:
Callouts

Obsidian Help: https://help.obsidian.md/Editing+and+formatting/Callouts.

Use callouts to include additional content without breaking the flow of your notes.

Note

Abstract

Aliases: summary, tldr

Info

Todo

Tip

Aliases: hint, important

Success

Aliases: check, done

Question

Aliases: help, faq

Warning

Aliases: caution, attention

Failure

Aliases: fail, missing

Danger

Alias: error

Bug

Example

Quote

Alias: cite

item.title: 010 - Creating a character
item.description:
Creating a character

Step 1: Create a concept

What sort of hero you want to play? As simple as: ‚Äúa brave warrior‚Äù, or as complicated as ‚Äúthe child of elven wanderers, but raised in a city dominated by humans and devoted to Sarenrae, goddess of the sun‚Äù.

Consider character‚Äôs personality, sketch out a few details about their past, and think about how and why they adventure.

Step 2: Start building ability scores

Your character‚Äôs ability scores each start at 10, and as you select your ancestry, background and class, you‚Äôll apply ability boosts, which increase a score by 2, and ability flaws, which decrease a score by 2.

Step 3: Select an ancestry

More info

Detailed information on ancestries is located in Pathfinder Core Book from page 34.

You‚Äôll make four decisions when you select your character‚Äôs ancestry:

  • Pick the ancestry itself.
  • Assign any free ability boosts and decide if you are taking any voluntary flaws. See ^ability-scores.
  • Select a heritage from those available within that ancestry, further defining the traits your character ws born with.
  • Choose an ancestry feat, representing an ability your hero learned from an early age.

Transclude of 013---Ability-scores
^ability-scores

Step 4: Pick a background

Your character‚Äôs background might represent their upbringing, an aptitude they‚Äôve been honing since their youth, or another aspect of their life before they became an adventurer. Backgrounds typically provide two specific ability boosts (one that can be applied to either of two specific ability scores, and on that is free), training in a specific skill, training in a Lore skill, and a specific skill feat.

Step 5: Choose a class

You don‚Äôt need to write down all of your character‚Äôs class features yet. You simply need to know which class you want to play, which determines the ability scores that will be most important for your characters.

Step 6: Determine ability scores

Do these three things:

  • Make sure you‚Äôve applied the ability boosts and ability flaws you‚Äôve noted in previous steps (from your ancestry, background, and class).
  • Apply four more ability boosts to your character‚Äôs ability scores, choosing a different ability score for each and increasing that ability score by 2.
  • Record your starting ability scores and ability modifiers, as determined using Ability modifiers table.
    Transclude of 011---Ability-modifiers

Remember

Each ability boost adds 2 to the base score of 10, and each ability flaw subtracts 2. You should have no ability score lower than 8 or higher than 18.

Step 7: Record class details

Make sure to record the following class features:

  • To determine your character‚Äôs total starting Hit Points, add together the number of Hit Points your character gains from the ancestry and the number of Hit Points they gain from their class.
  • The Initial Proficiencies section of your class entry indicates your character‚Äôs staring proficiencies ranks in a number of areas. Choose which skills your character is trained in and record those, along with the ones set by your class. If your class would make you trained in a skill you‚Äôre already trained in (typically due to your background), you can select another skill to become trained in.
  • See the class advancements table in your class entry to learn the class features your character gains at 1st level ‚Äî but remember, you already chose an ancestry and background. Some classes features require you to make additional choices, such as selecting spells.

Step 8: Buy equipment

At 1st level, your character has 15 gold pieces (150 silver pieces) to spend on armor, weapons, and other basic equipment.

Step 9: Calculate modifiers

If your proficiency rank for a statistic is trained, expert, master, and legendary, your bonus equals your character‚Äôs level plus another number based on the rank (2, 4, 6, and 8, respectively). If your character is untrained, your proficiency bonus is +0.

  • perception,
  • saving throws,
  • melee strikes and ranged strikes,
  • skills.

Step 10: Finishing details

Add the following details to your character sheet:

Alignment

Your character‚Äôs alignment in an indicator of their morality and personality. If your alignment has any components other than neutral, your character gains the traits of those alignment components. This might affect the way various spells, items, and creatures interact with your character.

Transclude of 012---Nine-alignments

Deity

Write down the deity your character worships, if any.

Age

Decide your character‚Äôs age and note it.

Gender and pronouns

Record your player‚Äôs gender, if applicable, and their pronouns.

Class DC

A class DC sets the difficulty for certain abilities granted by your character‚Äôs class. The DC equals 10 plus their proficiency bonus for their class DC (+3 for most 1st-level characters) plus the modifier for the class‚Äôs key ability score.

Hero points

Your character usually beings each game session with 1 Hero Point, and you gain additional Hero Points during sessions by performing heroic deeds or devising clever strategies. Your character can use Hero Points to gain certain benefits, such as starving off death or re-rolling a d20.

Armor class (AC)

To calculate AC, add 10 plus your character‚Äôs Dexterity modifier (up to their armor‚Äôs Dexterity modifier cap), plus their proficiency bonus with their armor, plus their armor‚Äôs item bonus to AC and any other permanent bonuses and penalties.

Bulk

Your character‚Äôs maximum Bulk determines how much weight they can comfortably carry. If they‚Äôre carrying a total amount of Bulk that exceeds 5 plus their Strength modifier, they are encumbered. A character can‚Äôt carry a total amount of Bulk that exceeds 10 plus their Strength modifier.

10 light items make up 1 Bulk.
